text_image_relationship.layout_style: Full-width rectangular miniature at top of page, followed by single-column text. A large ornamental initial ‘N’ in red and gold begins the text. Generous margins around text with rubrication and pen flourishes.

text_content.script_style: Gothic textura quadrata book hand with professional execution, red rubrics and occasional decorative flourishes

color_scheme.color_usage: Burnished gold reserved for initial and miniature frame; ultramarine blue for sky and seated figure’s robe; verdigris green for foliage; vermillion red for frame borders and rubrication. Layered washes with white highlights on tree trunk and folds. Color contrasts emphasize resting figure and tree. Pigments well-preserved with minimal darkening.

decorative_elements: Simple red pen-flourished tailpiece at bottom of text block

drawing_technique.line_style: Fine brown ink outlines with consistent weight; confident underdrawing visible beneath pigments
drawing_technique.shading_method: Subtle tonal washes in drapery folds; minimal hatch-style shading; white lead highlights on robes and tree bark
drawing_technique.perspective_handling: No true linear perspective; shallow depth indicated by overlapping figures and diminution of background buildings

content_theme.scene_description: A single outdoor scene under a large almond tree. Three figures occupy foreground: at left, a laborer in a gray tunic and hose raises a wooden mallet to crack almonds on a stump; at center, a standing figure in a purple tunic gathers cracked nuts into a basket placed on the stump; at right, a seated figure in a blue robe sorts and eats almonds, with two woven baskets of nuts beside them. The tree’s trunk is centered, its green foliage filling the upper miniature. Scattered almond shells and whole nuts litter the grassy ground. In the middle ground to left, a crenellated city wall with towers recedes horizontally, while rolling hills with sparse vegetation extend to the horizon. The composition balances the vertical tree with horizontal architectural elements. Costumes are simple linen and wool garments typical of peasants, pointed leather shoes, and practical head coverings. Actions depict harvest and consumption, reinforcing medicinal text below. The figures overlap slightly, creating a shallow pictorial space.

technical_features.preservation_condition: Overall good condition; vivid pigments retain original saturation. Slight cockling at corners, minimal flaking of red pigment in text. Evidence of 20th-century stabilization on lower margin.

Regular parchment ruling lines evident under UV

functional_analysis.intended_audience: Medical practitioners or literate laypersons interested in materia medica

analysis.scholarly_interpretation: This illuminated page, likely produced in a late 15th-century French workshop, exemplifies the intersection of practical medieval medicine and high art. It accompanies a recipe on the properties of sweet almonds, part of a larger herbal or medical miscellany modeled on the Tacuinum Sanitatis tradition. The vibrant palette—burnished gold, ultramarine, and verdigris—along with a precise Gothic textura hand, indicate patronage by a wealthy individual seeking both utility and prestige. The central image, dominated by a stately almond tree, organizes the secular labor of nut cracking and sorting into an aesthetically harmonious narrative. Such visual reinforcement served as an aide-mémoire for the text, enhancing comprehension of medicinal processes. Technically, the page reflects mature atelier practices: confident underdrawing, raised gesso for gold applications, and nuanced washes for modeling. Iconographically, the scene underscores the era’s emphasis on humoral balance—almonds as a remedy against intemperance. Comparative analysis places this work alongside Parisian medical manuscripts of the 1480s, yet its ornamental initial and landscape background suggest influence from Italianate miniaturists. The manuscript thus bridges Northern Gothic rigor and emerging Renaissance naturalism, illustrating a moment of stylistic synthesis in late medieval illumination.
